title: Portfolio Management Strategies
description: Master asset allocation, diversification, rebalancing, and building portfolios aligned with your risk tolerance and goals.
objectives: Understand modern portfolio theory and efficient frontier
Learn strategic vs tactical asset allocation
Master diversification across asset classes and geographies
Manage portfolio risk through hedging and position sizing

lessons.title: Asset Allocation Fundamentals

content.original: Asset allocation = Dividing portfolio among asset classes (equity, debt, gold, real estate). Strategic allocation = Long-term target based on goals, risk tolerance, time horizon. Tactical allocation = Short-term adjustments based on market conditions. Studies show 90%+ of portfolio return comes from allocation, not stock selection. Typical allocations: Aggressive (80-20 equity-debt), Moderate (60-40), Conservative (40-60). Include 5-10% gold for diversification. Rebalance when allocation drifts 5%+ from target.
content.simplified: Asset allocation means deciding how much money goes into stocks, bonds, gold, real estate etc. This decision is MORE important than which specific stocks you pick. Young investors can be aggressive (80% stocks, 20% bonds) because they have time to recover from losses. Older investors near retirement should be conservative (40% stocks, 60% bonds) to protect capital. Don't put all eggs in one basket - spread across different assets. When one goes down, others may go up.

lessons.aiSummary: Asset allocation = Dividing portfolio across asset classes. Strategic (long-term target) vs Tactical (market-based adjustment). 90% returns from allocation, not stock picking. Age-based: Aggressive (80-20), Moderate (60-40), Conservative (40-60).
keyTakeaways: Asset allocation determines 90%+ of portfolio performance
Age and risk tolerance guide allocation choices
Include 5-10% gold for inflation hedge and diversification
Write Investment Policy Statement documenting allocation strategy
commonMistakes: 100% allocation to single asset class (concentration risk)
Changing allocation based on short-term market moves (emotional)

lessons.title: Diversification Strategies

content.original: Diversification reduces unsystematic (company-specific) risk without reducing returns. Dimensions: (1) Across asset classes (equity, debt, gold, RE), (2) Within equity: sectors (IT, Banking, FMCG, Pharma), market caps (large, mid, small), (3) Geographic (domestic vs international), (4) Time (SIP vs lumpsum). Correlation matters - assets should move differently. 15-20 stocks provide adequate diversification. Beyond 30 stocks = diminishing returns. Don't confuse diversification with over-diversification (diworsification).
content.simplified: Diversification = Don't put all eggs in one basket. Spread across: Different types (stocks, bonds, gold), Different industries (tech, banking, healthcare), Different company sizes (big stable companies, smaller growing companies), Different countries (India + USA). The magic: When one investment falls, others may rise, smoothing your overall returns. Having 15-20 stocks is enough - having 100 stocks doesn't help much more and becomes difficult to manage.

lessons.aiSummary: Diversification = Risk reduction through spreading. Dimensions: Asset classes, Sectors, Market caps, Geography, Time. Optimal: 15-20 stocks. Correlation key: Assets should move independently. Avoid over-diversification.
keyTakeaways: Diversification is only free lunch in investing
15-20 stocks eliminate 90%+ of diversifiable risk
International diversification adds new dimension (US, developed, emerging)
Check correlation - buying similar stocks doesn't diversify
commonMistakes: Buying 10 IT stocks thinking it's diversified (sector concentration)
Diversifying only in bull market (should be constant strategy)

lessons.title: Rebalancing Your Portfolio

content.original: Rebalancing = Restoring portfolio to target allocation. Methods: (1) Calendar-based (annually, semi-annually), (2) Threshold-based (when asset drifts 5%+ from target), (3) Hybrid (check quarterly, rebalance if threshold breached). Rebalancing forces discipline: Sell high (overweight assets), Buy low (underweight assets). Tax considerations: Use new cash inflows to buy underweight assets. In taxable accounts, avoid triggering STCG. Rebalance within retirement accounts first (tax-free). Costs: Transaction charges, tax, impact cost.
content.simplified: Rebalancing = Bringing portfolio back to original plan. Example: You started with 70% stocks, 30% bonds. After year, stocks grew to 80%, bonds now 20%. Rebalancing means selling some stocks and buying bonds to get back to 70-30. This automatically makes you 'buy low, sell high'. When to rebalance: Once a year, or when any asset moves 5%+ from target. Smart trick: Instead of selling, add new money to lagging assets. This avoids tax on selling winners.

lessons.aiSummary: Rebalancing = Restoring target allocation. Methods: Calendar (annual), Threshold (5%+ drift), Hybrid. Forces sell high, buy low discipline. Tax-smart: Use new cash for underweight assets. Rebalance annually or when significant drift.
keyTakeaways: Rebalancing is contrarian - sell winners, buy losers (discipline)
Annual rebalancing sufficient for most investors
Use new investments to rebalance (tax-efficient)
Set calendar reminder to ensure consistency
commonMistakes: Never rebalancing (portfolio drifts far from plan)

lessons.title: Risk Management Techniques

content.original: Risk management = Protecting capital from significant losses. (1) Position sizing: Never allocate >5% to single stock, >10% to sector. (2) Stop-loss: Exit when stock falls X% (typically 15-25%) from purchase price or recent high (trailing stop). (3) Hedging: Use put options, inverse ETFs, or increase debt allocation during uncertainty. (4) Portfolio insurance: Maintain cash cushion (5-10%) for opportunities during crash. Risk-reward ratio: Aim for 1:2 or better (risk ‚Çπ1 to make ‚Çπ2). Kelly Criterion for optimal position sizing.
content.simplified: Risk management = Making sure you don't lose too much money. Key rules: (1) Don't put more than 5% of portfolio in one stock - if it goes to zero, you lose only 5%. (2) Set stop-loss: If stock falls 20% below your buy price, sell it automatically to limit damage. (3) Keep some cash (5-10%) always available - when market crashes, you can buy good companies cheap. (4) Don't risk ‚Çπ10 to make ‚Çπ11 - only take risks where potential gain is 2-3x the potential loss. Protection is as important as profit.

lessons.aiSummary: Risk management: Position sizing (max 5% per stock, 10% per sector), Stop-loss (15-25% below purchase), Hedging (options, inverse ETFs), Cash cushion (5-10%), Risk-reward 1:2+ ratio. Capital preservation crucial.
keyTakeaways: Position sizing prevents single stock from destroying portfolio
Stop-loss is insurance - small premium to avoid catastrophic loss
Cash is a position - opportunity cost < downside protection
Size positions by conviction and risk, not equal-weighting
commonMistakes: No position limits (one stock becomes 30% of portfolio)
Not using stop-loss (holding losers too long)
Being 100% invested always (no dry powder for crashes)
Equal-weighting all positions (ignores conviction and risk differences)

lessons.title: Building Your Investment Policy

content.original: Investment Policy Statement (IPS) = Written document outlining investment strategy. Components: (1) Goals with timelines and amounts, (2) Risk tolerance assessment, (3) Asset allocation targets and ranges, (4) Rebalancing triggers and frequency, (5) Stock selection criteria, (6) Buy/sell rules, (7) Review schedule. IPS prevents emotional decisions during volatility. Update IPS when life circumstances change (marriage, child, job change). Treat IPS as constitution for portfolio. Behavioral benefits > technical benefits. Warren Buffett's advice: Write rules in calm times, follow in storm.
content.simplified: Investment Policy Statement = Your personal investing rulebook written when mind is clear, not panicking. Include: Your goals (house down payment ‚Çπ20L in 5 years, retirement ‚Çπ3Cr in 25 years), How much risk you can take (can you sleep if portfolio drops 30%?), Your allocation plan (60% stocks, 30% bonds, 10% gold), When you'll rebalance, What types of stocks you'll buy, When you'll sell. When market crashes or soars, don't make emotional decisions - just follow your IPS. Update IPS only when your life changes (marriage, baby, new job), not when market changes.

lessons.aiSummary: IPS = Written investment constitution. Components: Goals, Risk tolerance, Asset allocation, Rebalancing rules, Selection criteria, Buy/sell discipline, Review schedule. Prevents emotional decisions. Update on life changes, not market changes.
keyTakeaways: Written plan beats mental plan (prevents rationalization)
IPS should fit on 1-2 pages (keep it simple)
Share IPS with family/advisor for accountability
Review IPS annually but change rarely
commonMistakes: No written plan (all decisions reactive and emotional)
Changing IPS based on market movements (defeats purpose)
Not reviewing IPS when life circumstances change
